misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the scores array, the corresponding names in the separate names array will still refer to the same students (i.e., the name-score pairing is preserved automatically).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(studentScores)` reorders only the `studentScores` array. It does not and cannot automatically rearrange `studentNames` to match, because the arrays are independent objects with separate storage. To keep pairs aligned, you must swap elements in both arrays during the sort, or use a single array of objects (e.g., `Student{name, score}`) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name may not match the highest score after sorting, because the name is taken from the original (unsorted) `studentNames` while the score is taken from the sorted `studentScores`.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Sorting Without Index Tracking
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when you sort one array in a parallel array structure, the corresponding elements in the other array will automatically stay aligned with their original partners. They think Arrays.sort() on the scores array will somehow also rearrange the names array to maintain the pairing.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Arrays.sort() only sorts the array it is called on. When you sort the studentScores array, the indices of the names array do not change. The student has misunderstood how parallel arrays work - they are completely independent. After sorting scores in ascending order, studentNames[numberOfStudents - 1] no longer refers to the student with the highest score; it refers to the last name that was entered, which is now paired with a different score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print an incorrect student name paired with the correct highest score, or the wrong score paired with a name.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topStudentName = studentNames[numberOfStudents - 1];
        int topStudentScore = studentScores[numberOfStudents - 1];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index-Based Array Sorting Without Maintaining Pairings
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that they can sort the scores array independently and then simply access the last position to get both the top student's name and score. They have not recognized that sorting breaks the correspondence between parallel arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: For parallel arrays to work correctly after sorting, you must either: (1) perform a coordinated swap operation on both arrays simultaneously using custom logic, (2) use an array of objects that keeps name-score pairs together, or (3) track indices during sorting. The student has only sorted one array and attempted to use indices as if the pairing were still intact. The actual Java behavior is that each array maintains its own order independent of other arrays.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - for the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), after sorting scores to [78, 85, 92], the code would print 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)' because Charlie is at index 2 in the names array (unchanged), but 92 is now at index 2 in the scores array (after sorting).

evidence.code_snippet:
String topStudentName = studentNames[numberOfStudents - 1];
        int topStudentScore = studentScores[numberOfStudents - 1];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are intended to be 'parallel', performing a sort operation on one will either automatically reorder the other to maintain the relationship, or they believe that the highest value will coincidentally align with the last entry in the name array after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, parallel arrays have no inherent connection within the JVM. They are only 'parallel' because the programmer accesses them using the same index. When the student calls `Arrays.sort(studentScores)`, the elements in the scores array are moved, but the elements in `studentNames` remain in their original positions. The student fails to realize that to maintain the data mapping, they must implement a custom sorting algorithm that performs identical swaps on both arrays.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned when sorting only one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array automatically keeps the names matched to the correct scores (i.e., the name at index i will still correspond to the score at index i after sorting), or that it’s still valid to pick the last name and last score independently after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(studentScores)` reorders ONLY the `studentScores` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate `studentNames` array. With parallel arrays, you must swap/move elements in BOTH arrays together during sorting (or sort indices/objects) to preserve the name↔score association.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints the wrong student name for the highest score).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting the scores array in ascending order, the highest score will be at the last position, and they can use that same position index to retrieve the corresponding name from the names array. They assume that sorting one array will maintain the parallel relationship between the two arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: When Arrays.sort() is called on only the scores array, only that array is rearranged in memory. The names array remains in its original order. The indices no longer correspond to the same student after this operation. For example, after sorting scores from [85, 92, 78] to [78, 85, 92], the name at index 2 is still "Charlie" (from the original order), not the name of the student with score 92. The student has broken the parallel relationship without realizing it.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the expected 'Top student: Bob (92)'

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since 'studentNames' and 'studentScores' are used together as parallel arrays, sorting the 'studentScores' array will automatically rearrange the 'studentNames' array to preserve the original index-based relationships (i.e., that Bob will stay associated with 92).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The 'parallel array' pattern is a manual convention used by programmers, but the JVM and the 'Arrays.sort' method have no knowledge of this relationship. Sorting one array only permutes that specific array, breaking the index-based association with any other array.
